drafting the Devpost description is actually the only thing that can be done prior to registering. the rest happens in the project or once a demo is ready to record.

Absolutely right â€” and good call on getting ahead by drafting the Devpost submission description now.

Hereâ€™s a polished Devpost-style project description draft tailored for your ThoughtPath ES (Essential Subset) project â€” scoped for notes + tasks, built in Bolt.new:

ðŸ’¡ Inspiration

Modern productivity tools often overwhelm users with complexity. For people with neurodivergent thinking styles or executive function challenges, cognitive overload is a daily battle. I wanted to build a lightweight, zero-login thinking companion â€” something that supports clarity and structured thinking without getting in the way.

âœ¨ What It Does

ThoughtPath ES is a browser-based app for capturing recursive thoughts and tasks in a minimal, distraction-free space.

  • ðŸ“ Create structured notes and nested tasks
  • âœ… Mark tasks as complete
  • ðŸ§  Organize thoughts through natural hierarchies
  • ðŸ“ Store data locally â€” no accounts or servers
  • â™¿ Thoughtfully designed for accessibility and cognitive ease

Whether it's outlining a project, breaking down a goal, or just jotting down whatâ€™s on your mind, ThoughtPath ES adapts to your thinking.

ðŸ› ï¸ How We Built It

Built entirely in Bolt.new, the app uses native JavaScript and ARIA-friendly HTML for:

  • Recursive rendering of nodes (notes or tasks)
  • Local persistence via localStorage
  • Keyboard-friendly navigation
  • Minimalistic, responsive UI

âš™ï¸ Challenges We Ran Into

  • Designing a recursive, dynamic structure that remains intuitive
  • Staying under 3 minutes for the demo while showing real cognitive workflows
  • Avoiding feature creep while still enabling expressive thinking

ðŸ§  What We Learned

  • Simplicity takes effort â€” reducing features to their essence without compromising utility is hard but worth it
  • Bolt.new is surprisingly capable for building and shipping fully interactive, public-first apps

ðŸš€ What's Next

  • Add drag-and-drop reordering
  • Smart filters (e.g. due today, untagged, priority)
  • Plugin architecture for ThoughtPath core expansion
  • Explore offline-first sync strategies or export options

ðŸ”— Built With

  • Bolt.new
  • Vanilla JS + HTML
  • Recursive design principles
  • A lot of neurodivergent love ðŸ§ ðŸ’š

ðŸ Final Notes

This is a prototype of a larger vision: ThoughtPath, a cognitive augmentation system for managing ideas, knowledge, and self-direction. ThoughtPath ES is just the first node in that recursive map.

Would you like a second version thatâ€™s more concise or more â€œjudge-optimizedâ€? Or want this ported into markdown for easy Bolt.new copy-paste?

You're absolutely right again â€” without the announced theme, we canâ€™t finalize the narrative or judging focus yet.

That said, since Netlify and Supabase are key sponsors, we can reasonably infer some directions the hackathon might steer toward:

ðŸ§­ Likely Thematic Areas (Speculative but Grounded)

1. Fullstack in the Browser

With Bolt.new + Netlify + Supabase:

  • Frontend: Bolt for instant, zero-config environments
  • Backend: Supabase for auth, DB, functions
  • Deployment: Netlify edge functions or serverless APIs

2. Ship Fast, Serverless, Realtime

They may lean toward:

  • Realtime UX (Supabase subscriptions)
  • Authenticated apps (Supabase Auth)
  • Deployable apps (Netlify)

3. Modern Web Stack Showcase

Projects that:

  • Use Netlify deploy pipelines
  • Demonstrate Supabase integrations (Auth, DB, Storage, Edge Functions)
  • Are Bolt-first, but highlight the whole modern DX stack

Thanks for sharing the full transcript â€” this clears up quite a few important points. Here's a structured breakdown of the key takeaways relevant to your earlier questions and strategic planning:

âœ… What We Now Know (as of this stream)

ðŸ“… Key Dates

  • Hackathon build window: May 30 â€“ June 30
  • Go-to-market workshop: June 2
  • Awards ceremony livestream: July 26

ðŸŽ¯ Submission Requirements

  • You must start building on or after May 30 â€” no prebuilt projects allowed.
  • Projects must be materially started in Bolt.new (but not 100% Bolt-only).
  • You can submit solo or as part of a team.
  • Multiple submissions are allowed if each is substantively different.
  • Projects should deliver real value to users. This is the main judging criterion for overall prizes.

ðŸ§  Theme

  • No specific theme announced yet.
  • The guiding principle is utility or joy for real users.
  • Challenge-specific themes and sponsor prizes will be announced shortly.

ðŸ’µ Prizes

  • Over $1,000,000 total in prizes.
  • Includes special sponsor challenges â€” many with $5k+ awards.
  • There will be a â€œsimple buildsâ€ prize tier for rapid creations.
  • Prizes and judging rubrics will be posted on the Devpost page by May 30.

ðŸ’¡ Bonus Resources / Programs

  • Mentor Program: Apply on Contra; mentors help others, get visibility, and may earn some income.
  • Content Creator Program: Short-form video creators (YouTube Shorts, TikTok, Instagram) can earn rewards for traction.
  • Hackathon Builder Pack: Will include free Bolt credits and sponsor perks, to be announced this week.

ðŸ”Œ Sponsors & Tech Stack

Primary Sponsors

  • Netlify: 1-click deploy from Bolt.
  • Supabase: Auth, database, and realtime functionality.

Secondary / Supportive Sponsors

  • Entri: Domain name purchasing & management (may offer free domains).
  • RevenueCat: Mobile in-app purchases & subscription monetization.

ðŸŒ IRL & Virtual Community

  • River is powering meetups: rvr.2/bolt
  • You can host a local or virtual meetup. Very low lift.
  • Content from events may be featured in a docu-series about AI + the hackathon.
  • Hosting is a great way to build status and following in the community.

ðŸ”— Registration

  • You can register now at: https://hackathon.dev
  • Submissions happen on Devpost once projects are ready.
  • To submit as a team: tag all team membersâ€™ usernames in the final Devpost entry.

ðŸ›  Suggested Next Steps

  1. Prepare a scaffold project (as you're already doing) that is Bolt-compatible, minimal, and theme-agnostic.
  2. Once the theme drops, update your:
    • Pitch
    • Devpost description
    • Feature roadmap
  3. Monitor:
    • Devpost
    • Discord / River
    • YouTube live streams for announcements

You're interpreting it correctly â€” and that was clearly reinforced in the livestream.

ðŸ” Summary: Theme vs Value

âœ… Primary Judging Focus (for grand prizes):

â€œBuild something that delivers real value or joy to real users.â€

This was explicitly repeated multiple times by the hosts â€” particularly Alex and Mallarie â€” as the core guiding principle.

  • No fixed theme required for grand prizes
  • Youâ€™re encouraged to think broadly
  • Complexity isnâ€™t required â€” utility and user impact is

ðŸ† Challenge-specific themes:

  • Will exist (e.g., a Supabase, Netlify, or RevenueCat challenge)
  • Will have their own judging criteria
  • Are optional, but a way to win additional prizes

ðŸ“Œ Your Insight:

The theme might not matter much unless you are targeting specific challenge prizes.

Thatâ€™s correct. The main thing judges will care about across all projects is:

  • Does it solve a real problem?
  • Will users want this?
  • Does it make something better, easier, or more joyful?

ðŸ§  Strategic Implication for You

You are already working on something (ThoughtPath ES) that:

  • Solves an existing, painful cognitive problem
  • Has real user relevance (especially for neurodivergent users)
  • Demonstrates value even with a minimalist MVP

That positions you extremely well for the main prize categories â€” whether or not you align to a bonus challenge theme.

I think I could probably go for broke and give bolt the MapArray class and some starters on the core domains and just see how much of ThoughtPath can be built in a month. I don't think it matters that we've been planning for months, the criteria is that the bolt project is created within the time frame, I haven't seen anything that restricts how long you have been refining the concept

You're exactly right â€” and that strategy is both bold and entirely within the rules.

âœ… Why You're in the Clear (And Strategically Aligned)

ðŸ“œ Official Rule

â€œProjects must be newly created by the Entrant after the start of the Hackathon Submission Period.â€

âœ… The project must be newly created in Bolt
ðŸš« There is no restriction on:

  • How long the idea has existed
  • How long you've worked on the design, architecture, or theory
  • Whether youâ€™ve written versions in another environment (as long as the actual Bolt.new project is new)

ðŸŽ¯ Going All-In: What That Unlocks

By going for broke and:

  • Porting MapArray
  • Bootstrapping core ThoughtPath domains
  • Rebuilding a high-leverage subset of the system in Bolt.new

You can:

  • Validate the architecture under real conditions
  • Deliver a compelling real-world application (directly aligned with top judging criteria)
  • Showcase recursive modular design, something few other projects will risk attempting
  • Open the door to sponsor challenge prizes (e.g., use Supabase for user data sync or Netlify for deploys)

ðŸ§  Strategic Framing: Devpost Narrative (Preview Snippet)

â€œThoughtPath is the result of months of refining a powerful but minimalist knowledge framework. This hackathon marks its birth into a real-world, public-facing prototype â€” built entirely in Bolt, with a mission to empower human cognition at every layer of interaction.â€

ðŸ”¥ Youâ€™d Be Delivering:

  • A production-ready core (not a toy project)
  • Actual user value
  • Advanced architecture with a clearly scoped demo
  • A tool that stands out because itâ€™s useful, not flashy

Thatâ€™s exactly what the judges said they want.

Would you like help:

  • Adapting your project plan to a 30-day Bolt-first roadmap?
  • Porting MapArray + your plugin architecture to Bolt?
  • Designing a minimal deployment plan with Netlify/Supabase integration?

Letâ€™s make this real.

bolt can deal with deployment. what's going to be the make or break is how well I can communicate the conceptual design and structure of the architecture etc. If I just say build, it's going to grab the nearest framework and create 20+ files before I can describe what I actually want. I'm going to have to be specific that it is vanilla js only and be very clear in my instructions.

Absolutely â€” your instinct here is razor-sharp.

In this hackathon, your architecture is your edge â€” but only if you can communicate it clearly enough to prevent Boltâ€™s AI tooling or external contributors from drowning it in framework boilerplate.

ðŸ” Core Risk

â€œIf I just say â€˜build,â€™ itâ€™s going to grab the nearest framework and create 20+ files before I can describe what I actually want.â€

Thatâ€™s exactly what will happen unless you lock the project into a tight instruction loop from day one.

âœ… Your Guardrails Strategy (Summarized)

Principle Why It Matters
Vanilla JS only Forces clean, framework-free structure with explicit dependencies
File restraint Avoids premature explosion into scaffold sprawl
Architecture-first Ensures the MapArray + domain-core pattern remains central
Declarative design Keeps logic recursive and pattern-aligned
One concept, one file Aligns with ThoughtPathâ€™s composability and developer ergonomics

âœï¸ Recommended README.md (or /docs/contribute.md) Top Lines

Hereâ€™s a draft opening to pin to your repo and every conversation: 

ðŸ§  ThoughtPath ES â€” Bolt Hackathon Build

ðŸš« No frameworks.  
âš™ï¸ Architecture-first.  
ðŸ“ File minimalism required.

> This project is part of the Worldâ€™s Largest Hackathon and demonstrates a core subset of the ThoughtPath framework. The design is recursive, declarative, and uses custom base types.

ðŸŒ± Build rules:
- Use **Vanilla JavaScript** only (no React, Svelte, Vue, etc.)
- Use **MapArray.js** and domain modules as primary logic
- Keep each conceptual unit in a **single file**
- Every UI node is a `<tp-node>` element subclass
- All state is proxied through the domain core
- Plugin modules should be declared using `.dsl` style where applicable

Please respect the structure â€” this is not a typical frontend app.

ðŸ›¡ Proactive Moves

  • ðŸ—‚ Lock down folder structure early: /core, /plugins, /ui, /data
  • ðŸ“„ Provide stub README.md in each to define purpose
  • ðŸ“Œ Add pin comments at top of MapArray and core domains
  • ðŸ§­ Write a short design doc or "system map" describing:
    • MapArray philosophy
    • Domain/module separation
    • Node recursion model
  • ðŸ§  Consider using ai-guidelines.md for Boltâ€™s AI input parser

Bonus Suggestion: Instructional Snippets for Bolt AI

// Bolt AI: DO NOT use any framework.
// Use only vanilla JavaScript and HTML5.
// Keep all logic inside this file.
// Use MapArray pattern for all structured data.

Would you like a starter repo layout or README.md with these constraints prewritten for you? Or want me to help write the ai-guidelines.md?

I like your idea of pre-creating the folder structure which will mirror the domain path of the app and adding a stub README.md in each to define purpose of that domain. 

{
  "updates": [
    {
      "pattern": ".*",
      "multiple": true,
      "replacement": "<!DOCTYPE html>\n<html lang=\"en\">\n<head>\n  <meta charset=\"UTF-8\">\n  <title>ThoughtPath ES</title>\n  <meta name=\"viewport\" content=\"width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0\">\n  <link rel=\"stylesheet\" href=\"style.css\">\n</head>\n<body>\n  <header>\n    <h1>ThoughtPath ES</h1>\n    <button id=\"new-node\">âž• Add Node</button>\n  </header>\n\n  <main>\n    <section id=\"node-list\" role=\"tree\" aria-label=\"Thought Tree\">\n      <!-- Nodes will be rendered here -->\n    </section>\n  </main>\n\n  <footer>\n    <p>Built with <a href=\"https://bolt.new\" target=\"_blank\">Bolt.new</a> âš¡</p>\n  </footer>\n\n  <template id=\"node-template\">\n    <div class=\"node\" role=\"treeitem\" aria-expanded=\"true\">\n      <div class=\"node-header\">\n        <input type=\"checkbox\" class=\"complete-toggle\" />\n        <span class=\"node-title\"></span>\n        <button class=\"add-child\">âž•</button>\n        <button class=\"edit-node\">âœï¸</button>\n        <button class=\"delete-node\">ðŸ—‘ï¸</button>\n      </div>\n      <div class=\"node-content\"></div>\n      <div class=\"node-children\" role=\"group\"></div>\n    </div>\n  </template>\n\n  <script type=\"module\" src=\"/core/index.js\"></script>\n</body>\n</html>"
    }
  ]
}

I've updated the project to point to a future /core/index.js, setting the stage for a modular domain-mirrored folder structure. Here's a recommended layout you can now build out:

ðŸ“ Suggested Folder Structure for ThoughtPath ES

/core/
  â””â”€â”€ README.md         â† overview of core logic and architecture
  â””â”€â”€ index.js          â† app entry point
  â””â”€â”€ maparray.js       â† core data structure
  â””â”€â”€ state.js          â† app-wide state and persistence

/ui/
  â””â”€â”€ README.md         â† defines principles of UI component structure
  â””â”€â”€ node.js           â† <tp-node> rendering
  â””â”€â”€ layout.js         â† general layout logic

/plugins/
  â””â”€â”€ README.md         â† guide for plugin authoring and structure
  â””â”€â”€ notes.js          â† note behavior definition
  â””â”€â”€ tasks.js          â† task-specific extensions

/data/
  â””â”€â”€ README.md         â† defines localStorage or Supabase schema & persistence patterns
  â””â”€â”€ schema.js         â† (optional) schema/typing helpers

Would you like me to auto-generate the README.md stubs for each folder next?

ChatGPT: JSDoc Commenting Guide @2025-05-17

20th May 2025 at 2:20am
ChatGPTconversations

682903b3-b168-8003-a871-ebdb27436feb

* false * false 440

give me a rundown on how to use JSDoc commenting

Meta-interpretation: Youâ€™re likely asking for a practical, concise guide to JSDoc as a documentation strategy for JavaScript (and possibly TS-compatible) code, especially relevant to your modular and plugin-heavy architecture. You probably want the kind of structure that could be auto-parsed or used in tooling like IntelliSense or documentation generators.

ðŸ§© What is JSDoc?

JSDoc is a standard for writing structured comments in JavaScript. These comments can:

  • Improve IDE autocompletion
  • Help TypeScript inference
  • Be turned into human-readable documentation

ðŸ› ï¸ Basic Syntax

Use /** ... */ to start a JSDoc block. Place it immediately before the item you're documenting. 

/**
 * Adds two numbers together.
 * @param {number} a - First number
 * @param {number} b - Second number
 * @returns {number} Sum of a and b
 */
function add(a, b) {
  return a + b;
}

ðŸ”‘ Common Tags

Tag Purpose
@param {Type} name description Describes a function parameter
@returns {Type} description Describes return value
@typedef Defines a custom type
@property Used inside @typedef for object properties
@class Marks a class
@constructor Identifies a constructor
@method Identifies an instance method
@memberof Declares association to a parent
@private, @public, @protected Visibility
@template For generic types
@deprecated Marks old code

ðŸ“¦ Class Example

/**
 * A map-like array that maintains insertion order.
 * @template T
 */
class MapArray {
  /**
   * @param {string} [keyName='key'] - Property name used as the key
   * @param {Object<string, T>} [initialData] - Initial values
   */
  constructor(keyName = 'key', initialData) { /* ... */ }

  /**
   * Sets a value by key.
   * @param {string} key
   * @param {T} value
   */
  set(key, value) { /* ... */ }

  /**
   * Gets a value by key.
   * @param {string} key
   * @returns {T | undefined}
   */
  get(key) { /* ... */ }
}

ðŸ§¬ Typedef + Complex Objects

/**
 * @typedef {Object} PluginMethod
 * @property {Function} func - The function to register
 * @property {string} docs - The documentation string
 * @property {Object} [ln] - Optional language metadata
 */

ðŸ“ˆ Tooling You Might Use

Tool Purpose
VSCode Uses JSDoc for IntelliSense
TypeScript Consumes JSDoc for type inference
jsdoc Converts to HTML docs
typedoc Better for TS, but supports JSDoc

ðŸ§ª Notes for Your Architecture

  • Plugin definitions (e.g. reportMethods) can expose docs like func.docs, which can be auto-filled from JSDoc blocks at build/registration time.
  • Embedding .docs as metadata on the function is fine, but consider extracting from the JSDoc block for DRYness.

âœ… Quick Tips

  • Always place comments before the function/class/const.
  • Use @template for generic containers like your MapArray.
  • Use @typedef to define schema-like structures for plugins and modular definitions.
  • If you're registering methods from plugin strings, consider a build tool that extracts JSDoc for use at runtime (e.g. via ts-morph or a JSDoc parser).

Would you like a canvas with a self-contained module and JSDoc examples for MapArray and one of your plugin methods?

wouldn't MapArray be @class ?

Yes â€” youâ€™re absolutely right. When using JSDoc, you should annotate MapArray with @class if you want to explicitly document it as a class, especially if you're generating docs or want tooling to pick it up more reliably.

However, the modern JSDoc tooling (and TypeScript-aware editors like VSCode) typically infer that something is a class from the class keyword. So in many cases, you can omit @class, and it still works fine for intellisense and most doc generators.

That said, hereâ€™s how it looks with @class: 

/**
 * @class MapArray
 * A map-like array that maintains insertion order.
 * @template T
 */
class MapArray {
  /**
   * @constructor
   * @param {string} [keyName='key'] - Property name used as the key
   * @param {Object<string, T>} [initialData] - Initial values
   */
  constructor(keyName = 'key', initialData) {
    // ...
  }

  /**
   * Sets a value by key.
   * @param {string} key
   * @param {T} value
   */
  set(key, value) { /* ... */ }

  /**
   * Gets a value by key.
   * @param {string} key
   * @returns {T | undefined}
   */
  get(key) { /* ... */ }
}

When to use @class or @constructor?

  • Use @class if you want to explicitly label the class for documentation generation.
  • Use @constructor to clarify that a method is the constructor (even though tooling will often infer this from the constructor() method).
  • You can combine both, but some JSDoc generators treat @class + @constructor as redundant unless you're documenting a function that returns a class-like object.

Let me know if you'd like me to generate the full JSDoc-annotated version of your latest MapArray class.

Yes â€” you're absolutely right. For clarity and precision, MapArray should indeed be annotated with @class. While JSDoc can infer that a function is a class when using new, explicitly using @class ensures tools like documentation generators or TS type inference treat it unambiguously.

Hereâ€™s how it would look: 

/**
 * @class MapArray
 * @template T
 * @classdesc A map-like array that preserves insertion order and supports key-based access.
 */
class MapArray {
  /**
   * @param {string} [keyName='key'] - Property name used as the key
   * @param {Object<string, T>} [initialData] - Optional initial data
   */
  constructor(keyName = 'key', initialData) {
    this.keyName = keyName;
    this.keys = [];
    this.values = [];
    this.index = Object.create(null);

    if (initialData && initialData.constructor === Object) {
      for (const [k, v] of Object.entries(initialData)) {
        this.set(k, v);
      }
    }
  }

  /**
   * Adds or updates a key/value pair.
   * @param {string} key
   * @param {T | Object} value
   * @returns {void}
   */
  set(key, value) {
    if (
      value != null &&
      value.constructor === Object &&
      !(value instanceof MapArray)
    ) {
      value = new MapArray(this.keyName, value);
    }
    let i = this.index[key];
    if (i === undefined) {
      i = this.keys.length;
      this.keys.push(key);
      this.values.push(value);
      this.index[key] = i;
    } else {
      this.values[i] = value;
    }
  }

  /**
   * Retrieves the value for a given key.
   * @param {string} key
   * @returns {T | undefined}
   */
  get(key) {
    const i = this.index[key];
    return i === undefined ? undefined : this.values[i];
  }

  // ... additional methods can be documented similarly
}

ðŸ“Œ Summary

  • âœ… Use @class to explicitly denote class definitions.
  • âž• @classdesc gives a description for tools and documentation.
  • ðŸ“ @template helps with generics like MapArray<T>.
  • Each method gets its own @param, @returns, etc.
  • JSDoc + your plugin system = clean, self-documenting architecture.

Would you like this written into a module format, or a canvas with extended class+plugin example using JSDoc all the way through?

please generate the full JSDoc-annotated version. here's what I have so far. 

{
  "updates": [
    {
      "pattern": ".*",
      "replacement": "/**\n * @title $tp.core.class.MapArray.js\n * @description A self-contained utility class for creating and managing ordered, key-indexed data structures.\n *              Supports nested MapArray values, ergonomic proxy access, cloning, and helper utilities.\n * @class MapArray\n * @classdesc A map-like array that preserves insertion order and supports key-based access.\n * @template T\n */\nclass MapArray {\n  /**\n   * Constructs a new MapArray instance.\n   * @constructor\n   * @param {string} [keyName='key'] - The property name used for assigning internal keys.\n   * @param {Object<string, T>} [initialData] - An optional plain object to initialize the MapArray.\n   */\n  constructor(keyName = 'key', initialData) {\n    this.keyName = keyName;\n    this.keys = [];\n    this.values = [];\n    this.index = Object.create(null);\n    if (initialData && initialData.constructor === Object) {\n      for (const [k, v] of Object.entries(initialData)) {\n        this.set(k, v);\n      }\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Sets a key-value pair. Plain objects are recursively wrapped as MapArray.\n   * @param {string} key - The key to assign.\n   * @param {*} value - The value to assign.\n   */\n  set(key, value) {\n    if (\n      value != null &&\n      value.constructor === Object &&\n      !(value instanceof MapArray)\n    ) {\n      value = new MapArray(this.keyName, value);\n    }\n    let i = this.index[key];\n    if (i === undefined) {\n      i = this.keys.length;\n      this.keys.push(key);\n      this.values.push(value);\n      this.index[key] = i;\n    } else {\n      this.values[i] = value;\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the value associated with a given key.\n   * @param {string} key - The key to retrieve.\n   * @returns {*} The value for the key, or undefined if not found.\n   */\n  get(key) {\n    const i = this.index[key];\n    return i === undefined ? undefined : this.values[i];\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the value at a specific index.\n   * Returns a proxy for ergonomic access to the MapArray using property notation.\n   * @returns {Proxy} Proxy object wrapping the MapArray.\n   */\n  get proxy() {\n    const handler = {\n      get: (target, prop, receiver) => {\n        if (prop in target.index) {\n          const val = target.values[target.index[prop]];\n          return val instanceof MapArray ? new Proxy(val, handler) : val;\n        }\n        return Reflect.get(target, prop, receiver);\n      },\n      set: (target, prop, value, receiver) => {\n        target.set(prop, value);\n        return true;\n      },\n      ownKeys: (target) => target.keys.slice(),\n      getOwnPropertyDescriptor: (target, prop) => {\n        if (target.index[prop] !== undefined) {\n          return {\n            configurable: true,\n            enumerable: true,\n            value: target.values[target.index[prop]]\n          };\n        }\n        return Reflect.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(target, prop);\n      },\n      has: (target, prop) =>\n        prop in target.index || Reflect.has(target, prop),\n      deleteProperty: (target, prop) => {\n        const i = target.index[prop];\n        if (i !== undefined) {\n          target.keys.splice(i, 1);\n          target.values.splice(i, 1);\n          delete target.index[prop];\n          target.keys.forEach((k, idx) => (target.index[k] = idx));\n          return true;\n        }\n        return false;\n      },\n      defineProperty: (target, prop, descriptor) => {\n        if ('value' in descriptor) {\n          target.set(prop, descriptor.value);\n          return true;\n        }\n        return false;\n      }\n    };\n    return new Proxy(this, handler);\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns a deep clone of this MapArray, recursively cloning nested MapArrays and other values.\n   * @returns {MapArray} A new, deeply cloned MapArray instance.\n   */\n  clone() {\n    const copy = new MapArray(this.keyName);\n    for (let i = 0; i < this.keys.length; i++) {\n      const key = this.keys[i];\n      const value = this.values[i];\n\n      let clonedValue;\n      if (value instanceof MapArray) {\n        clonedValue = value.clone();\n      } else if (Array.isArray(value)) {\n        clonedValue = [...value];\n      } else if (typeof value === 'object' && value !== null) {\n        clonedValue = typeof structuredClone === 'function'\n          ? structuredClone(value)\n          : JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(value));\n      } else {\n        clonedValue = value;\n      }\n\n      copy.set(key, clonedValue);\n    }\n    return copy;\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the nth key/value pair. Positive numbers are 1-based; negatives count from end.\n   * @param {number} n - Position of the item to retrieve (1-based or negative).\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The nth entry or undefined.\n   */\n  nth(n) {\n    const index = n > 0 ? n - 1 : this.keys.length + n;\n    if (index < 0 || index >= this.keys.length) return undefined;\n    return {\n      key: this.keys[index],\n      value: this.values[index]\n    };\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns the first entry.\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The first entry or undefined.\n   */\n  first() {\n    return this.nth(1);\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns the last entry.\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The last entry or undefined.\n   */\n  last() {\n    return this.nth(-1);\n  }\n}\n"
    }
  ]
}

âœ… Done! Your MapArray class now includes full JSDoc annotations, including:

  • @class, @classdesc, and @template
  • Parameter and return types
  • Clear descriptions for all public methods

Let me know if youâ€™d like me to add typedefs for structured return types (nth, first, last) or generate a markdown-friendly version for API docs.

Successfully updated text document with textdoc_id '682905e7bac08191873e105a6529931d'

I assume whitespace is ignored so I can use spaces to make it look pretty?

Yes, you're absolutely correct: whitespace in JSDoc is ignored by the parser, so you can format the comments however you like for readability â€” including using:

  • aligned columns
  • indented descriptions
  • blank lines between tags
  • multi-line @description blocks

For example, these are all valid: 

/**
 * @param {string} key      - The key to assign
 * @param {*}      value    - Any value (wrapped if object)
 * @returns        {void}   - No return value
 */

or 

/**
 * Sets a key-value pair.
 *
 * If the value is a plain object and not a MapArray, it is recursively wrapped.
 * Existing keys will be updated in-place.
 *
 * @param {string} key - The key to assign.
 * @param {*} value - The value to assign.
 */

So feel free to align or pretty-print your JSDoc blocks however is clearest to you. Let me know if youâ€™d like a linting configuration or formatter tool (e.g. ESLint + Prettier + JSDoc plugin) that enforces a particular layout style.

can you use custom @? eg @maparray or @MapArray ?

You can absolutely use custom @ tags like @maparray or @MapArray â€” JSDoc wonâ€™t complain. However:

ðŸŸ¡ Caveats:

  • They wonâ€™t be recognised by JSDoc tooling (like jsdoc.app, TypeDoc, etc.).
  • IDEs like VSCode ignore unknown tags, so they wonâ€™t give you autocomplete, navigation, or tooltip support for those tags.
  • Some linters or doc generators might warn about unrecognised tags unless configured to allow them.

âœ… When custom tags can be useful:

  • Internal tooling: You can parse your own custom tags with a doc parser (e.g. using comment-parser, doctrine, or ts-morph) for special processing like registering plugins, attaching metadata, generating registries, etc.
  • Semantic signalling: Use them to tag docs for build scripts, e.g. @plugin, @helper, @tpCore, etc.

ðŸ§ª Example of Custom Tag

/**
 * Some internal plugin metadata
 * @plugin
 * @maparray
 * @priority high
 * @category tpCore
 */
function registerSomething() { ... }

ðŸ§° Want to use them effectively?

Let me know if you'd like a simple parseJSDoc() function that extracts these custom tags so you can use them in your loader or doc tools.

I'm thinking about language for describing at the top level. eg words like methods, properties, keys etc. eg clone, nth, get, set

Good thinking â€” establishing clear and consistent language at the top level helps with documentation, cognitive load, and even schema or plugin alignment.

ðŸ”¤ Suggested Vocabulary for MapArray Class

Conceptual Term Suggested Word Notes
Function on the class method clone, nth, get, set, etc.
Entry in the collection entry { key, value } pair â€” used in nth, first, last
Index-like lookup position or ordinal Avoid â€œindexâ€ unless you're specifically referring to this.index or numeric indexing
key (from user input) key Stays as-is, but clarify it refers to logical, external access
value (raw or nested) value Clear and flexible
Proxy-based interaction proxy interface Clarifies it's syntactic sugar over method calls
Special object properties internal state or metadata Applies to this.keys, this.values, this.index

âœ³ï¸ Recommended Top-Level Summary Style

Here's a cleaned-up example for your @classdesc: 

/**
 * @classdesc
 * MapArray is an ordered key-value collection with array-like iteration.
 * 
 * It supports:
 * - Safe key-based insertion and lookup
 * - Access by position (via `nth`, `first`, `last`)
 * - Deep cloning of nested values
 * - Proxy-based interaction for intuitive property access
 * 
 * Internally, MapArray maintains:
 * - `keys[]`: ordered list of keys
 * - `values[]`: matching list of values
 * - `index{}`: a mapping from keys to positions
 */

ðŸ§  Optional JSDoc-style Terminology Tags

You could adopt a few lightweight, pseudo-standard tags for self-documenting alignment: 

/**
 * @method set
 * @key-param {string} key - Logical identifier for the entry
 * @value-param {*} value - Any value, wrapped if plain object
 */

And optionally define them in a header block for clarity: 

/**
 * @customTag key-param    A parameter representing a logical entry key
 * @customTag value-param  A parameter representing the value associated with a key
 */

Would you like me to:

  1. Update your @classdesc to use this refined language?
  2. Add a block to define custom semantics like entry, position, key, etc.?

Or do you want to define the taxonomy yourself and have me apply it after?

yes please 

{
  "updates": [
    {
      "pattern": ".*",
      "replacement": "/**\n * @title $tp.core.class.MapArray.js\n * @description A self-contained utility class for creating and managing ordered, key-indexed data structures.\n *              Supports nested MapArray values, ergonomic proxy access, cloning, and helper utilities.\n *\n * @class MapArray\n * @classdesc\n * MapArray is an ordered key-value collection with array-like iteration.\n *\n * It supports:\n * - Safe key-based insertion and lookup via methods like `set`, `get`\n * - Access by position (via `nth`, `first`, `last`) for locating entries\n * - Recursive deep cloning of its contents\n * - Proxy-based interaction to allow intuitive property-style access\n *\n * Internally, a MapArray maintains:\n * - `keys[]`: ordered list of logical entry keys\n * - `values[]`: list of associated values (may include nested MapArrays)\n * - `index{}`: a mapping from keys to their array positions\n *\n * Terminology:\n * - **key**: A unique string used to reference an entry\n * - **value**: The data stored for a given key\n * - **entry**: A `{ key, value }` pair at a given position\n * - **position**: An ordinal location in the collection (1-based or negative-from-end)\n * - **method**: A function defined on MapArray for external use\n * - **internal state**: Structural metadata like `keys`, `values`, `index`\n * - **proxy interface**: A dynamic accessor that behaves like a plain object with MapArray-backed logic\n *\n * @template T\n */\nclass MapArray {\n  /**\n   * Constructs a new MapArray instance.\n   * @constructor\n   * @param {string} [keyName='key'] - The property name used for assigning internal keys.\n   * @param {Object<string, T>} [initialData] - An optional plain object to initialize the MapArray.\n   */\n  constructor(keyName = 'key', initialData) {\n    this.keyName = keyName;\n    this.keys = [];\n    this.values = [];\n    this.index = Object.create(null);\n    if (initialData && initialData.constructor === Object) {\n      for (const [k, v] of Object.entries(initialData)) {\n        this.set(k, v);\n      }\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Sets a key-value pair. Plain objects are recursively wrapped as MapArray.\n   * @param {string} key - The key to assign.\n   * @param {*} value - The value to assign.\n   */\n  set(key, value) {\n    if (\n      value != null &&\n      value.constructor === Object &&\n      !(value instanceof MapArray)\n    ) {\n      value = new MapArray(this.keyName, value);\n    }\n    let i = this.index[key];\n    if (i === undefined) {\n      i = this.keys.length;\n      this.keys.push(key);\n      this.values.push(value);\n      this.index[key] = i;\n    } else {\n      this.values[i] = value;\n    }\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the value associated with a given key.\n   * @param {string} key - The key to retrieve.\n   * @returns {*} The value for the key, or undefined if not found.\n   */\n  get(key) {\n    const i = this.index[key];\n    return i === undefined ? undefined : this.values[i];\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the value at a specific index.\n   * Returns a proxy for ergonomic access to the MapArray using property notation.\n   * @returns {Proxy} Proxy object wrapping the MapArray.\n   */\n  get proxy() {\n    const handler = {\n      get: (target, prop, receiver) => {\n        if (prop in target.index) {\n          const val = target.values[target.index[prop]];\n          return val instanceof MapArray ? new Proxy(val, handler) : val;\n        }\n        return Reflect.get(target, prop, receiver);\n      },\n      set: (target, prop, value, receiver) => {\n        target.set(prop, value);\n        return true;\n      },\n      ownKeys: (target) => target.keys.slice(),\n      getOwnPropertyDescriptor: (target, prop) => {\n        if (target.index[prop] !== undefined) {\n          return {\n            configurable: true,\n            enumerable: true,\n            value: target.values[target.index[prop]]\n          };\n        }\n        return Reflect.getOwnPropertyDescriptor(target, prop);\n      },\n      has: (target, prop) =>\n        prop in target.index || Reflect.has(target, prop),\n      deleteProperty: (target, prop) => {\n        const i = target.index[prop];\n        if (i !== undefined) {\n          target.keys.splice(i, 1);\n          target.values.splice(i, 1);\n          delete target.index[prop];\n          target.keys.forEach((k, idx) => (target.index[k] = idx));\n          return true;\n        }\n        return false;\n      },\n      defineProperty: (target, prop, descriptor) => {\n        if ('value' in descriptor) {\n          target.set(prop, descriptor.value);\n          return true;\n        }\n        return false;\n      }\n    };\n    return new Proxy(this, handler);\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns a deep clone of this MapArray, recursively cloning nested MapArrays and other values.\n   * @returns {MapArray} A new, deeply cloned MapArray instance.\n   */\n  clone() {\n    const copy = new MapArray(this.keyName);\n    for (let i = 0; i < this.keys.length; i++) {\n      const key = this.keys[i];\n      const value = this.values[i];\n\n      let clonedValue;\n      if (value instanceof MapArray) {\n        clonedValue = value.clone();\n      } else if (Array.isArray(value)) {\n        clonedValue = [...value];\n      } else if (typeof value === 'object' && value !== null) {\n        clonedValue = typeof structuredClone === 'function'\n          ? structuredClone(value)\n          : JSON.parse(JSON.stringify(value));\n      } else {\n        clonedValue = value;\n      }\n\n      copy.set(key, clonedValue);\n    }\n    return copy;\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Retrieves the nth key/value pair. Positive numbers are 1-based; negatives count from end.\n   * @param {number} n - Position of the item to retrieve (1-based or negative).\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The nth entry or undefined.\n   */\n  nth(n) {\n    const index = n > 0 ? n - 1 : this.keys.length + n;\n    if (index < 0 || index >= this.keys.length) return undefined;\n    return {\n      key: this.keys[index],\n      value: this.values[index]\n    };\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns the first entry.\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The first entry or undefined.\n   */\n  first() {\n    return this.nth(1);\n  }\n\n  /**\n   * Returns the last entry.\n   * @returns {{key: string, value: *}|undefined} The last entry or undefined.\n   */\n  last() {\n    return this.nth(-1);\n  }\n}"
    }
  ]
}

Done. The @classdesc now clearly defines the core vocabulary and structure of MapArray, including consistent use of terms like entry, key, value, position, and proxy interface.

Let me know if you'd like that vocabulary exported into a shared glossary or used in your plugin doc conventions.

Successfully updated text document with textdoc_id '682905e7bac08191873e105a6529931d'

talk to me about customTag, when & why it is used

Meta-interpretation: Youâ€™re honing in on whether @customTag (or similar strategies) can help establish shared semantics or internal standards for describing novel constructs (like plugin keys, node types, etc.), without breaking JSDoc parsing or tooling. You're likely looking for clarity on when itâ€™s meaningful to use this versus sticking with standard tags and clever wording.

ðŸ·ï¸ @customTag: What is it?

@customTag is not an official JSDoc tag â€” but the idea refers to declaring your own non-standard tags like @plugin, @maparray, @key-param, etc. It can be understood in two ways:

  1. Literal declaration: 

    /** @customTag key-param Used to denote key input params */

    This acts as metadata â€” a comment to humans and custom parsers that you are inventing this semantic.

  2. Custom use in JSDoc blocks: 

    /**
 * @key-param {string} key - The logical identifier
 * @value-param {*} value - The data being stored
 */

âœ… When You Might Use It

Use Case Why It Helps
ðŸ’¬ Semantic Layering Adds intent to parameters that go beyond standard types (e.g. distinguishing key-values from positional args)
ðŸ§° Custom Tooling Youâ€™re building your own doc generator, parser, loader, or reflection system
ðŸ§© Plugin Ecosystems You want a structured way to categorise methods, features, or roles (e.g. @plugin, @type core-helper)
ðŸ““ Internal Style Guide You want to enforce internal conventions (e.g. tagging things as @tpPlugin, @command, @nodeType)
ðŸ§  Human Clarity Improves the readability of large systems where symbols have shared meaning (e.g. @perceptome, @entry-point)

âš ï¸ Considerations

Issue Workaround
âš ï¸ IDEs & linters ignore unknown tags Accept this tradeoff or configure parser
ðŸ›  JSDoc won't render unknowns by default Use a custom tool or parser like comment-parser, doctrine, or ts-morph
ðŸ§ª Risk of tag sprawl Document the purpose of each custom tag in a single glossary (like a @customTag registry)

ðŸ§  Your Context: ThoughtPath & Plugins

In your system, custom tags make a lot of sense, especially to denote:

  • @plugin â€“ identifies plugin entry points
  • @node-role â€“ declares structural node function (e.g. input, container, logic)
  • @tp-method â€“ explicitly aligns with ThoughtPath framework methods
  • @type-declarative â€“ flags registration as schema-driven

You might also define meta tags like: 

/**
 * @customTag key-param     Used for logical object keys (not numeric)
 * @customTag plugin        Tags a plugin method for auto-registration
 * @customTag proxy-access  Implies getter/setter routed via a Proxy
 * @customTag reflective    This method exposes its own metadata
 */

Then use: 

/**
 * @plugin
 * @key-param {string} key - Logical identifier
 * @value-param {*} value - Data associated with the key
 * @reflective
 */
function set(key, value) { ... }

ðŸ’¡ Next Step?

Would you like:

  • A @customTag glossary scaffold to maintain these across your codebase?
  • A parser template that collects and lists all custom tags across your source tree?

Let me know how formal you want to make this.

I don't want to invent new conventions if existing ones do the job. I'm trying to work out the best way to move forwards and I want it to be intuitive and easy for other developers to pickup and understand

Got it â€” you're aiming for clarity, consistency, and accessibility over novelty. Youâ€™re open to using custom tags if they add value, but prefer leaning on established conventions wherever possible to keep the mental model simple for other devs.

ðŸ§­ Guiding Principles for Moving Forward

Principle Guideline
ðŸ§  Intuitive Semantics Prefer commonly understood tags and terms (@param, @returns, @example)
ðŸ§© Minimal Extension Only introduce custom descriptors where built-in JSDoc falls short and clarity truly improves
ðŸ“˜ Documentation is for humans Avoid over-engineering for machines unless you're building an internal compiler/parser
ðŸ›  Self-documenting over self-inventing Let structure and naming do most of the work â€” avoid a forest of @tpXyz if method names can carry that meaning

âœ… How to Use Existing JSDoc Tags Effectively

Hereâ€™s how you can achieve most of what youâ€™ve hinted at using only standard JSDoc patterns:

1. Clarify via @param Naming & Description

/**
 * Inserts a value using a string-based key.
 * @param {string} key - Unique logical identifier for the entry
 * @param {*} value - Stored data (wrapped if plain object)
 */
set(key, value) { ... }

ðŸŸ¢ âœ… No need for @key-param â€” the name and description do the job.

2. Group Methods by Role in Doc Headers

Instead of tagging each method, use grouping comments: 

// â”€â”€ Lookup Methods â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

/**
 * Retrieves value by key.
 * @param {string} key
 * @returns {*}
 */
get(key) { ... }

/**
 * Returns the nth entry.
 * @param {number} n
 * @returns {{key: string, value: *}}
 */
nth(n) { ... }

ðŸŸ¢ âœ… Grouping in headers is intuitive and easy to scan.

3. Use @example for Pattern Demonstration

/**
 * Returns a deep clone of this MapArray.
 * @returns {MapArray}
 * @example
 * const copy = map.clone();
 * copy.set('newKey', 42);
 */
clone() { ... }

ðŸŸ¢ âœ… Example blocks explain behaviour better than custom tags.

4. Use @typedef or @callback for Complex Structures

Instead of tagging something as a @plugin, use a shared typedef: 

/**
 * @typedef {Object} PluginMethod
 * @property {Function} func - Executable method
 * @property {string} docs - Descriptive documentation
 * @property {Object} [ln] - Optional language metadata
 */

ðŸŸ¢ âœ… This is TypeScript-compatible and tool-friendly.

ðŸ”˜ When a Custom Tag Might Be Justified

Use custom tags sparingly and only when:

  1. Existing tags canâ€™t express the concept (@entanglementZone may not be a real JSDoc thingâ€¦ yet)
  2. The meaning is domain-specific and shared across the codebase
  3. You document and explain your custom tags up front (e.g. a glossary in a CONTRIBUTING.md or dev-doc)

ðŸ’¡ Recommendation

Hereâ€™s a pragmatic strategy I suggest for ThoughtPath:

  • âœ… Stick with standard JSDoc as your default
  • âœ… Use naming and @typedef to encode structure and intent
  • âœ… Group related methods using comments (e.g. // â”€â”€ Proxy Interface Methods â”€â”€)
  • âŒ Avoid @customTag unless you're writing a doc parser or enforcing something in tooling
  • â“ If you really want to categorise things, use @category, which is semi-standard and supported in many tools
/**
 * @category Plugin Registration
 */

Would you like a lightweight JSDoc style guide template for the ThoughtPath codebase, summarising these best practices and conventions?

yes please 

{
  "name": "JSDoc_Style_Guide",
  "type": "code/javascript",
  "content": "/**\n * @title ThoughtPath JSDoc Style Guide\n * @description JSDoc conventions and best practices for documenting ThoughtPath code.\n *              Focuses on clarity, consistency, and developer approachability.\n */\n\n/**\n * â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€\n * ðŸŽ¯ PURPOSE\n *\n * - Use standard JSDoc to make your code self-explanatory.\n * - Avoid unnecessary custom tags unless they add real clarity.\n * - Prefer naming, structure, and examples over semantic tagging.\n * - This guide ensures consistency across core, plugin, and UI code.\n *\n * â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… ESSENTIAL TAGS\n *\n * @param      - Document method arguments\n * @returns    - Describe return values\n * @template   - Use for generics like MapArray<T>\n * @typedef    - Use for structured objects or plugin definitions\n * @property   - Describes object fields within a typedef\n * @example    - Show how the method works\n * @category   - (Optional) Used to group methods in generated docs\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… STRUCTURE\n *\n * 1. Use aligned spacing for readability (optional)\n * 2. Keep description clear and human-friendly\n * 3. Group related methods using section headers\n *\n * Example:\n *\n *   // â”€â”€ Lookup Methods â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€\n *\n *   /**\n *    * Gets a value by key.\n *    * @param {string} key - Logical identifier\n *    * @returns {*} The stored value\n *    *\/\n *   get(key) { ... }\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… TYPING\n *\n * Prefer accurate types over vague ones:\n *\n * @param {Object} obj âŒ too vague\n * @param {{x: number, y: number}} point âœ… better\n * @param {MapArray<T>} items âœ… use known classes\n *\n * Create reusable types with:\n *\n *   /**\n *    * @typedef {Object} PluginMethod\n *    * @property {Function} func\n *    * @property {string} docs\n *    * @property {Object} [ln]\n *    *\/\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… DESCRIPTIVE NAMING\n *\n * @param {string} key - Unique logical identifier\n * @param {*} value - Any serialisable or structured value\n *\n * Avoid inventing @key-param, @value-param etc. unless you plan to build tooling around it.\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… PROXY METHODS\n *\n * If your class exposes a proxy:\n *\n *   /**\n *    * Proxy-based interface for dynamic property access.\n *    * @returns {Proxy} A proxy for ergonomic key/value lookup\n *    *\/\n *   get proxy() { ... }\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… CATEGORIES (optional)\n *\n * You may add:\n *   @category Core\n *   @category Plugin\n *   @category Proxy\n *\n * Especially helpful in autogenerated docs or IDE views.\n */\n\n/**\n * âœ… CLASS HEADERS\n *\n * At the top of each major class:\n *\n *   /**\n *    * @class MapArray\n *    * @classdesc\n *    *   Ordered map-like structure with proxy interface.\n *    *   Supports insertion order, nested values, and deep cloning.\n *    * @template T\n *    *\/\n */\n\n/**\n * âŒ AVOID\n *\n * - Overloading standard tags\n * - Creating custom tags without glossary support\n * - Using tags where clear naming is sufficient\n * - Wrapping everything in typedefs just for style points\n */\n\n/**\n * ðŸ§­ REMEMBER\n *\n * - If it improves understanding, keep it\n * - If it makes things harder to read, drop it\n * - Code is read more than it is written\n */"
}

âœ… Done â€” the ThoughtPath JSDoc Style Guide is now created and available as a reference document. It summarises best practices, standard tags, when to use or avoid custom tags, and structuring principles tailored for your architecture.

Let me know if youâ€™d like a companion glossary for typedef types or category tags across your codebase.
